ext_descriptions.ext_description:
The ahead_or_behind type is used to specify whether a given time is ahead of coordinated universal time, behind coordinated universal time or is coordinated universal time.
Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) is the international time standard. It is the current term for what was commonly referred to as Greenwich Meridian Time (GMT). Zero (0) hours UTC is midnight in Greenwich England, which lies on the zero longitudinal meridian. Coordinated universal time is based on a 24 hour clock; therefore, afternoon hours such as 4 pm are expressed as 16:00 UTC (sixteen hours, zero minutes).
a given time is ahead of coordinated universal time;
a given time is coordinated universal time;
a given time is behind coordinated universal time.

The date_time_or_event_occurrence type allows for the designation of a
or an .
A date_time_select type allows for the designation of a , , or a .
A day_in_month_number is the position of the specified day in a month.
The value of the integer shall be between 1 and 31 inclusive.

A day_in_week_number is the position of the specified day in a week as defined in ISO 8601.
Monday is day number 1, Tuesday is day number 2, Wednesday is day number 3, Thursday is day number 4, Friday is day number 5, Saturday is day number 6, and Sunday is day number 7.
The value of the integer shall be between 1 and 7 inclusive.

A day_in_year_number is the position of the specified day in a year.
The 27th day of March is day 86 in years that are not leap years and day 87 in leap years.
The value of the integer shall be between 1 and 366 inclusive.

An hour_in_day is the hour element of a specified time on a 24 hour clock. Midnight shall be represented by the value zero.
The hour_in_day corresponding to 3 o'clock in the afternoon is 15.
Although ISO 8601 allows two representations for midnight, 0000 and 2400, this part of ISO 10303 restricts the representation to the first value.
The value of the integer shall be between 0 and 23 inclusive.
A minute_in_hour is the minute element of a specified time.
The value of the integer shall be between 0 and 59 inclusive.

A month_in_year_number is the position of the specified month in a year as defined in ISO 8601.
January is month number 1, February is month number 2, March is month number 3, April is month number 4, May is month number 5, June is month number 6, July is month number 7, August is month number 8, September is month number 9, October is month number 10, November is month number 11, and December is month number 12.
The value of the integer shall be between 1 and 12 inclusive.
A second_in_minute is the position of the specified second in a minute.

ext_description.p: The value of the real number shall be between 0 to 60.0 inclusive.
ext_description.note: A value of 60 allows for leap seconds.

The mean solar time is determined by the rotation of the earth. Leap seconds are added as required, usually in the middle or at the end of a year, and ensure that the legal time does not differ from the non-uniform mean solar time by more than one second, in spite of the variations of the earth rotation.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
A week_in_year_number is the position of the specified calendar week as defined in ISO 8601.
Week number 1 is the week containing the first Thursday of the year. This is equivalent to saying that week number 1 contains the date 4th January.
The value of the integer shall be between 1 and 53.

A year_number is the year as defined in the Gregorian calendar. The year_number shall be completely and explicitly specified using as many digits as necessary to unambiguously convey the century and year within the century. Truncated year numbers shall not be used.
ISO 8601:1988 defines the Gregorian calendar.
The year_number corresponding to the first manned landing on the moon is 1969 (not 69).
The value of the integer shall be greater than 1581.

A calendar_date is a type of
defined as a day in a month of a year as defined in ISO 8601.
the day element of the .
the month element of the .

ext_description.p: The entity shall define a valid calendar date.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
A coordinated_universal_time_offset is the oriented offset (specified in hours and possibly minutes) from the coordinated universal time. The offset is defined in ISO 8601 The offset value shall be positive.
Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) is the international time standard. It is the current term for what was commonly referred to as Greenwich Meridian Time (GMT). Zero (0) hours UTC is midnight in Greenwich England, which lies on the zero longitudinal meridian. Coordinated universal time is based on a 24 hour clock; therefore, afternoon hours such as 4 pm are expressed as 16:00 UTC (sixteen hours, zero minutes).
A coordinated_universal_time_offset is used to relate a time to coordinated universal time by an offset (specified in hours and minutes) and a direction.
the number of hours by which a time is offset from coordinated universal time.
the number of minutes by which a time is offset from coordinated universal time.
the direction of the offset.
the value of the number of minutes offset used to compute the coordinated_universal_time_offset, either the value of minute_offset or 0.
The hour_offset shall be a positive number, less than 24.
The minute_offset shall be a positive number, less than or equal to 59.

If the value of sense specifies that there is no offset from the Coordinated Universal time, hour_offset and actual_minute_offset shall both be equal to zero. If either hour_offset or actual_minute_offset is different from zero, the value of sense shall specify that there is an offset, either ahead or behind, from the Coordinated Universal time.

A date is the identification of a day or week or month in a year. A date may be either a
or an , or a , or a . The date is defined in ISO 8601.
the year in which the date occurs.
A date_and_time is a moment of time on a particular day.
the date element of the date time combination.
the time element of the date time combination.

A date_role is a role for a A date_role is an incompletely modeled concept and requires population related entity data types to form a complete date_role.
A date_role is a role for a
and a description of that role.

ext_description.p:
the
by which the date_role is known.
ext_description.note: The meaning of this attribute can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.

ext_description.p:
the
that characterizes the date_role. The value of the attribute need not be specified.
ext_description.note: This attribute is an upwardly compatible addition to date_role as specified in ISO 10303-41:1994.

ext_description.p:
Each date_role shall be the
in at most one .
ext_description.note:
The
data type is defined in basic_attribute_schema of this part of ISO 10303.
A template for constraining the population of the entity data types defined in the basic_attribute_schema is described in annex E.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
A date_time_role a role for for a moment of time on a particular day. A date_time_role is an incompletely modeled concept that requires population of related entity data types to form a complete date_time_role

and a description of that role.

the
by which the date_time_role is known.

This attribute is an upwardly compatible addition to date_time_role as specified in ISO 10303-41:1994.

ext_description.p:
Each date_time_role shall be the
in at most one .

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
An event_occurrence is the fact of a transition between states at some point in time. The description of the event_occurrrnece can provide an implicit representation of either the state preceeding the event_occurrence or the state after the event_occurrence.
The point in time of the existence may not be known in terms of a calendar date before the event_occurrence actually happens. One reason, why the event_occurrence cannot always be expressed as a calendar date, is that the event_occurrence is not possible to plan, for example a break down of a machine.
The event_occurrence 'start of production' implicitly declares that the before the event_occurrence a product was not in production.

the
that characterizes the event_occurrence. The value of the attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.note: The context in which id is used as a discriminating characteristic can be identified in an annotated Express schema that uses or specializes this entity, or by default, in an agreement of common understanding between partners sharing this information.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
the
by which the event_occurrence is known.

An event_occurrence_context_role establishes a context for an . An event_occurrence is an incompletely modeled concept and requires population of related entity data types for forme a complete event_occurrence_context_role
For the
'start of production' the product, for which production starts, is the context for that .

the
that characterizes the event_occurrence_context_role. The value of the attribute need not be specified.

the
by which the event_occurrence_context_role is known.

An event_occurrence_relationship is a relationship between two s with a description of their relationship.
The role of event_occurrence_relationship can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or by default, in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.
This entity, together with the
entity, is based on the relationship template that is described in annex E.3.

the
by which the event_occurrence_relationship is known.

the
that characterizes the event_occurrence_relationship. The value of the attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p: one of the instances of s that is a part of the relationship.
ext_description.note: The meaning of this attribute can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.

ext_description.p: the other instance of . If one element of the relationship is dependent upon the other, this attribute shall be the dependent one.
ext_description.note: The meaning of this attribute can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: An event_occurrence_role establishes a role for an event_occurrence. An event_occurrence_role is an incompletely modeled concept and requires population of related entity data types to form a complete event_occurrence_role

the
that characterizes the event_occurrence_role. The value of the attribute need not be specified.

the
by which the event_occurrence_role is known.

A local_time is an instance of time represented on a 24-hour clock by hour, minute, and second. The instance is expressed in the local time zone and the offset with the coordinate universal time shall be specified. This concept is defined in ISO 8601.
This construct is used to represent a moment of time whereas
represents amounts of time.
the number of hours.
the number of minutes. The value of the attribute need not be specified.
the number of seconds. The value of the attribute need not be specified.
the offset of the local time zone to the coordinated universal time.
The entity shall define a valid time. The second_component attribute shall only exist if the minute_component attribute exists.

An ordinal_date is a type of
defined as a day of a year. This concept is defined in ISO 8601.
the day element of the .

The day_component shall be between 1 and 365 if the
is not a leap year. Otherwise the day_component shall be between 1 and 366.

A relative_event_occurrence is a type of
that takes place with an offset to an .
'Five days after start of production' is an example for a relative_event_occurrence, where 'five days' is an offset relative to an
'start of production'.
the relative_event_occurrence is defined with respect to the base_event.
the amount of time that passes between the occurrence of the base_event and the relative_event_occurrence. A negative offset specifies that the relative_event_occurrence occurs before the base_event.

A time_interval is the identification of an interval of time. This concept is defined in ISO 8601.
'Strike duration', 'delay of production', and 'Christmas holidays' are examples for time_intervals.

ext_description.note: The context in which id is used as a discriminating characteristic can be identified in an annotated Express schema that uses or specializes this entity, or by default, in an agreement of common understanding between partners sharing this information.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
the
by which the time_interval is known.

the
that characterizes the time_interval. The value of the attribute need not be specified.

The role of time_interval_relationship can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or by default, in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.
This entity, together with the
entity, is based on the relationship template that is described in annex E.3.

the
by which the time_interval_relationship is known.

the
that characterizes the time_interval_relationship. The value of the attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p:
one of the instances of
that is a part of the relationship.
ext_description.note: The meaning of this attribute can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.

ext_description.p: the other instance of . If one element of the relationship is dependent upon the other, this attribute shall be the dependent one.
ext_description.note: The meaning of this attribute can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: A time_interval_role is a role that may be assigned to a time_interval and includes a description of that role. The assignment of a role to a time_interval is accomplished by the time_interval_assignment entity data type.

ext_description.p:
the
that characterizes the time_interval_role. The value of the attribute need not be specified.
ext_description.note: The meaning of this attribute can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
the
by which the time_interval_role is known.

A time_interval_with_bounds is a type of . The time_interval_with_bounds is bounded either on one side or both sides. If neither secondary_bound nor duration are specified, the time interval begins at the point in time identified by primary_bound and has no specified end point.
'From 01-01-1999 to 31-12-1999' is an example for a both side bounded time_interval_with_bounds, 'from 01-01-2000 on', and 'until start of production' are examples for a one side bounded time_interval_with_bounds.
one of the bounds of the time_interval_with_bounds. The value of this attribute need not be specified.
the other bound of the time_interval_with_bounds. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

the
that specifies the length of a time_interval_with_bounds. If positive, the time_interval_with_bounds is a lower bounded time_interval_with_bounds, else an upper bounded time_interval_with_bounds. The value of this attribute need not be specified.

ext_description.p: Either the primary_bound or the secondary_bound or both shall be specified.

ext_descriptions.ext_description: The combination of primary_bound, secondary_bound and duration shall not be specified.
If primary_bound is specified and secondary_bound is not specified and if duration is specified, the duration shall be positive.
If primary_bound is not specified and secondary_bound is specified, duration shall be specified and the duration shall be negative.
A time_role is a definition of a role for a local_time. The assignment of the role to a local_time is accomplished by the time_assignment entity data type.

ext_description.p:
the
by which the time_role is known.
ext_description.note: The meaning of this attribute can be defined in the annotated EXPRESS schemas that use or specialize this entity, or in an agreement of common understanding between the partners sharing this information.
This attribute is an upwardly compatible addition to time_role as specified in ISO 10303-41:1994

ext_description.p:
Each time_role shall be the
in at most one .
ext_description.note:
The
data type is defined in basic_attribute_schema of this part of ISO 10303.
A template for constraining the population of the entity data types defined in the basic_attribute_schema is described in annex E.

ext_descriptions.ext_description:
A week_of_year_and_day_date is a type of
defined by identifying the week within a year and the day within that particular week.
the day element of the .
the week element of the .
A year_month is a type of defined as a month of a year.
the month element of the .

The acyclic_event_occurrence_relationship function determines whether the graph of instances of the entity data type
that contains relation as one of its links contains a cycle. This function may be used to evaluate either an
or any of its subtypes.
The function returns TRUE if no cycle has been detected. Otherwise it returns FALSE.
The algorithm of the function is explained in annex E.2.
This function is not used in this schema. It is defined here because other ISO 10303 integrated resources and application protocols that use the
entity include rules that use this function.

(input) the candidate
to be checked.

(input) the set of instances of the entity data type
for which the function is searching in the
parameter of the relation argument.

(input) the fully qualified entity name of a type of
entity.

The function returns TRUE if no cycle has been detected. Otherwise it returns FALSE.

This function is not used in this schema. It is defined here because other ISO 10303 integrated resources and application protocols that use the

The duration_is_negative function determines whether a given is negative. It returns TRUE if the is negative. Otherwise, it returns FALSE.

(input) the candidate
that is being checked.
The duration_is_positive function determines whether a given is positive. It returns TRUE if the is a positive. Otherwise, it returns FALSE.

(input) the candidate
that is being checked.
The leap_year function checks whether or not a particular year contains 366 days instead of 365 days, known as a leap year. Leap years occur every for years.
an integer representing a particular year in the Gregorian calendar.

The valid_calendar_date function determines whether the components of a
indicate a valid . If the
is valid, the function returns TRUE. Otherwise it returns FALSE.

(input) the candidate
that is to be checked.

The valid_time function determines whether a candidate
has a
if it has a . It returns FALSE if the condition is not met. Otherwise it returns TRUE.

(input) the candidate
that is to be checked.
